articles.headline: When Running 250 Miles Is the Easy Part
articles.snippet: A man with autism, his devoted mother and a seemingly endless race. A story of resilience and love.
articles.abstract: A man with autism, his devoted mother and a seemingly endless race. A story of resilience and love.
articles.lead_paragraph: Zach Bates waited quietly in the morning twilight, outfitted in some of the gear he would need to cover 250 miles: fabric guards to keep the dust out of his shoes, a face covering, sunglasses, a hydration pack and water bottles, hiking poles and a green hat with a neck flap to block the sun. The race, just moments away, would be the hardest thing he had ever taken on.
articles.byline: By Rebecca Byerly and Maansi Srivastava

articles.headline: The Crypto Industry Spent Over $130 Million on the Election. It Paid Off.
articles.snippet: The spending spree fueled a string of victories on Tuesday for congressional candidates who had expressed support for cryptocurrencies.
articles.abstract: The spending spree fueled a string of victories on Tuesday for congressional candidates who had expressed support for cryptocurrencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Locked in a tight race for the U.S. Senate in Ohio, the Republican candidate Bernie Moreno got a major boost in the weeks before the election: $40 million from the cryptocurrency industry.

articles.headline: What a Trump Victory Means for Tech
articles.snippet: Another Trump presidency will be good for crypto and Elon Musk, but every big tech company may not benefit from a more hands-off approach to antitrust.
articles.abstract: Another Trump presidency will be good for crypto and Elon Musk, but every big tech company may not benefit from a more hands-off approach to antitrust.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has won the 2024 presidential election. Follow live updates here.

articles.headline: Another Jolt of Uncertainty for a Global Economy Mired in It
articles.snippet: The U.S. presidential election result has ensured a sharp turn in economic policy expected to upend global commerce and diverge from decades of American norms.
articles.abstract: The U.S. presidential election result has ensured a sharp turn in economic policy expected to upend global commerce and diverge from decades of American norms.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. presidential election is over. What remains is a disorienting miasma of fresh economic uncertainty.

articles.headline: Inflation Infused the Vote. But Could Trump Reignite It?
articles.snippet: Many Americans fretted about inflation as they headed out to vote. But Donald J. Trump’s approach comes with risks of a renewed boost.
articles.abstract: Many Americans fretted about inflation as they headed out to vote. But Donald J. Trump’s approach comes with risks of a renewed boost.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans have been chafing against higher prices for years now, propelling unhappy voters to the polls and helping to deliver the White House to the Republican candidate, Donald J. Trump.

articles.headline: Trump’s Newest Economic Guides Are Not Like His Old Ones
articles.snippet: A little-known investment banker, a former hedge fund star and an acolyte of George Soros have the president-elect’s ear.
articles.abstract: A little-known investment banker, a former hedge fund star and an acolyte of George Soros have the president-elect’s ear.
articles.lead_paragraph: To staff his first term as president, Donald J. Trump attracted a group of largely by-the-book aides and advisers who produced an economic record — corporate tax cuts and financial deregulation — that would have been in place in any typical Republican administration.
articles.byline: By Rob Copeland, Maureen Farrell and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: Harris Asked Voters to Protect Democracy. Here’s Why It Didn’t Land.
articles.snippet: In more than 200 interviews, voters worried not about an endangered country, but about paying rent.
articles.abstract: In more than 200 interviews, voters worried not about an endangered country, but about paying rent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Her campaign pitch was moving, even high-minded. If Vice President Kamala Harris were elected to the White House, she would safeguard the ideals of a good nation. Voters had a choice, she said: democracy, constitutional rights and bedrock freedoms — or Donald J. Trump’s “chaos and division.”

articles.headline: Resist or Retreat? Democratic Voters Are Torn About Whether to Keep Fighting.
articles.snippet: Many who became activists during the first Trump administration are questioning if they can summon the strength to do it all over again.
articles.abstract: Many who became activists during the first Trump administration are questioning if they can summon the strength to do it all over again.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cynthia Shaw worked at a polling place in the Detroit suburbs on Election Day and went to bed “still hopeful” that Vice President Kamala Harris could win, she said. By Wednesday morning, she was bereft, her head pounding.
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei and Jenna Russell

articles.headline: How Trump Connected With So Many Americans
articles.snippet: Donald Trump’s campaign was a blend of comedy, fury, optimism, darkness and cynicism. “He gets us,” some voters concluded.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump’s campaign was a blend of comedy, fury, optimism, darkness and cynicism. “He gets us,” some voters concluded.
articles.lead_paragraph: The forces that propelled President-elect Donald J. Trump to victory will be endlessly analyzed. Many Americans woke up on Wednesday morning shocked that he could win again. But there is no doubt about one thing: Mr. Trump was a ferociously effective campaigner.

articles.headline: For Black Women, ‘America Has Revealed to Us Her True Self’
articles.snippet: Kamala Harris’s resounding defeat affirmed the worst of what many Black women believed about their country, even as some looked to the future with a wary determination.
articles.abstract: Kamala Harris’s resounding defeat affirmed the worst of what many Black women believed about their country, even as some looked to the future with a wary determination.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has won the 2024 presidential election. Follow live updates here.
articles.byline: By Erica L. Green and Maya King

articles.headline: Civilian Terror: Russia Hits Ukrainian Cities With Waves of Drones
articles.snippet: Moscow has been using decoy drones with no warheads to overwhelm defenses, and surveillance drones and strike drones to gather intelligence, Ukrainian officials said.
articles.abstract: Moscow has been using decoy drones with no warheads to overwhelm defenses, and surveillance drones and strike drones to gather intelligence, Ukrainian officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Russian troops march relentlessly forward with fierce assaults in Ukraine’s east, Moscow is unleashing a different form of terror on civilians in towns and cities: a wave of long-range drone strikes that has little precedent in the 32-month-old war.

articles.headline: The Fed Cuts Rates, but the Path Ahead Is Less Clear
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve is reducing rates in response to cooling inflation. Donald Trump’s presidential victory has pumped up uncertainty.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve is reducing rates in response to cooling inflation. Donald Trump’s presidential victory has pumped up uncertainty.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials cut interest rates on Thursday, their second reduction of 2024 and the latest sign that policymakers believe that inflation is finally coming under control.

articles.headline: How Trump Won, and How Harris Lost
articles.snippet: He made one essential bet: that his grievances would become the grievances of the MAGA movement, and then the G.O.P., and then more than half the country. It paid off.
articles.abstract: He made one essential bet: that his grievances would become the grievances of the MAGA movement, and then the G.O.P., and then more than half the country. It paid off.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s chief pollster, Tony Fabrizio, had seen just about everything in his three races working for the controversy-stoking former president. But even he seemed to be bracing for bad news.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan

articles.headline: Tech Giants Face a Familiar Uncertainty With Trump
articles.snippet: Apple, Amazon, Google, Meta and others learned during the last Trump administration to expect the unexpected when it came to Washington scrutiny and support.
articles.abstract: Apple, Amazon, Google, Meta and others learned during the last Trump administration to expect the unexpected when it came to Washington scrutiny and support.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a meeting with Google’s Larry Page, Apple’s Tim Cook and other tech leaders in 2016, President-elect Donald J. Trump told the gathering, “I’m here to help you folks do well.”
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and David McCabe

articles.headline: Before the Election, Tech C.E.O.s Were Quietly Courting Trump
articles.snippet: The executives of tech’s biggest companies largely ignored Donald Trump before the 2016 election. This time around, they’re far more friendly.
articles.abstract: The executives of tech’s biggest companies largely ignored Donald Trump before the 2016 election. This time around, they’re far more friendly.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump first campaigned for president eight years ago, tech executives largely ignored him. They later atoned for their disregard by making a televised walk through the lobby of Trump Tower in New York for a 90-minute meeting with the president-elect.
articles.byline: By Tripp Mickle and David McCabe
